Summary Dr. Frank Zhang is a Principal Performance Engineer at IBM Corporation, Massachusetts. He received his M.S. and Ph.D. in operations research from Northeastern University, and B.S. and M.S. in mechanical engineering from Hefei University of Technology. He acquired technical skills in C/C++, Java, JEE, WebLogic, WebSphere, Oracle (an OCP), Sybase, DB2, Calypso, jmeter, and RPT. While developing industry applications, he has learned a few financial and other products and their business process flows, such as equities and equity derivatives, credit and interest derivatives, front, middle and back office processing flows. Sourcing products and processing flows. What he boasts most however is still his analytical skills and common senses. 
 
Dr. Zhang started his career as an algorithm developer and published related works on Journals such as “Computational Optimization and Applications” and “Computers and Operations Research”. Soon after his brief engagement at Bell Labs, he shifted his interests to software performance engineering in solving industry problem for financial firms. He then worked at Morgan Stanley, Instinet and Bear Stearns, covering front office, middle office and back office financial products with high volume and complexities. In 2009, he moved to Massachusetts to start a dream restaurant with his friends. It turned out that his performance optimization tricks are limited to software products, not applicable to a dining business. He since then returned to his comfort zone and continues his pursuit of ever better software performance. Experience Capacity and Performance Architect IBM 2010  – Present (5 years) Greater Philadelphia Area Capacity and Performance Architect for LotusLive SAAS Product offering for IBM Smart Cloud for Business 
 
Monitors and provides assessments of the existing and future capacity of server, storage, and network components that makes up the LotusLive production environment. 
 
Provides technical support assistance to team members using capacity planning tools and processes to predict and avoid application impacts due to capacity issues. 
 
Collaborates with support organizations to identify data and metrics that are useful in predicting capacity issues in the LotusLive SAAS production environment, 
 
Presents capacity assessments and action plans to LotusLive Operations Management on a monthly basis or as priorities dictate. 
 
Recommends tools, processes and procedures to enhance the capacity planning process. SR. CAPACITY AND PERFORMANCE SPECIALIST, IT Operations - OLD & NEW IT INFRASTRUCTURE CIGNA 2006  –  2010  (4 years) Responsible for the planning, management, and the delivery of CPU and SAN Storage DASD capacity for CIGNA's enterprise WINTEL infrastructure, ensuring that all business applications meet or exceed service levels for end-to-end application performance. Analyzed distributed system application performance trends, identified improvement opportunities, and initiated application and infrastructure changes or modifications to mitigate the effect of unplanned business demand on enterprise resources. Managed and participated in third-level root cause analysis and resolution of complex end-to-end WINTEL production performance problems.  
 
Accomplishments:  
 
Supported the IT Strategy by continuing to find opportunities for cost savings by utilizing three primary avenues – application segmentation, virtualization (VMWARE 3.5x) and server consolidation along with reuse of existing computing capacity, and hardware refreshes of outdated hardware technology. In 2006, avoided the purchase of 61 servers, resulting in $3,882,513 of cost savings. 
 
Awards: 
 
Received a CIGNA Everyday Champions award for work in support of EQM PVS testing initiatives providing valuable insight in analyzing the results of testing. Projects cited were critical enterprise initiatives that included CGI Acclaim PVS testing and the July and October 2008 testing of the Defined Care Platform. CAPACITY AND PERFORMANCE SPECIALIST, IT ASP/OUTSOURCE MANAGEMENT AND PURCHASING CIGNA 2002  –  2006  (4 years) Responsible for the planning, management, and the delivery of CPU and SAN Storage DASD capacity for CIGNA's enterprise WINTEL infrastructure, ensuring that all business applications meet or exceed service levels for end-to-end application performance. Analyzed distributed system application performance trends, identify improvement opportunities, and initiate application and infrastructure changes or modifications to mitigate the effect of unplanned business demand on enterprise resources. Granted sign-off authority for budget items not found in the annual enterprise WINTEL infrastructure hardware and software budget that had a capital cost of less than $50k. Lead the development of planning deliverables in support of the development of the annual enterprise WINTEL infrastructure hardware and software budget.  
 
Accomplishments 
 
In 2003, completed the first ever WINTEL enterprise capacity plan using data gathered from across all CIGNA business organizations. 
 
Collaborated with the CLXP program in 2004 to reduce overall capital spending by $2.7m less than projected, and to reduce the installed base of Wintel servers by at least 20% by 1st Qtr '05 by migrating of l 000+ Windows NT 4.0 servers to a consolidated Microsoft Windows 2003 server infrastructure.  
 
Supported the IT Strategy by continuing to find opportunities for cost savings by utilizing three primary avenues – application segmentation, and server consolidation along with reuse of existing computing capacity, and hardware refreshes of outdated hardware technology. From 2003 to 2005 avoided the purchase of 309 servers for a total cost savings of $15.8M. 
 
Awards 
 
In 2004, received a certificate of appreciation from the HIPAA Enterprise Project team for support throughout the initiative.  
 
Received a CIGNA Everyday Champions award in 2006 for work in the stabilization of the Online Referral Tracking tool that was based out of the Phoenix office. NOC TECHNICAN IV CIGNA 1997  –  2002  (5 years) Member of the Performance Planning Group, which focused on eliminating network outages by monitoring CIGNA's Wide Area Network for abnormal trends in circuit and FEP utilization. Also monitored the health of other managed objects, such as routers, token ring, and Ethernet hubs, E-Mail Gateways, and NT Network Components.  
 
Specific responsibilities included: 
 
Exception reporting on server health and performance for over 1300+ Windows NT 4.0 file, application, and print servers.  
 
Reported servers exceeding threshold criteria to management and LAN Operations personnel for corrective action. 
 
Exception reporting on Ethernet and Token Ring hub health and performance.  
 
Reported hubs exceeding threshold criteria to management and LAN Operations personnel for corrective action. 
 
Exception reporting on router health and performance for corporate access, distribution, and core routers in the Windsor Data Center. 
 
Reported routers exceeding threshold criteria to management and LAN Operations personnel for corrective action. 
 
Administrator for the VDCAPP04/05 servers and backup administrator for the VDCAPP06 and Conference Plus application servers. 
 
Coordinated and performed weekly backups and data recovery procedures. 
 
Tested network management products for Year2K compliance. 
 
Accomplishments 
 
Actively worked with Performance Planning team to achieve Lost Productivity Avoidance of $1.25M in 2001. This was accomplished by reducing potential network outages and responding to and completing service requests in a timely manner.
